audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 4, Lesson 1. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Books for Unit 3 and Unit 4.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 3 Student Book. Whisper read the story “My Desert Blog.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
Multimodal mini-lesson. Listen to the sound.
audio.notes: Articulation video for long sound "BOAT" card.

audio.transcription: This is the sound-spelling card for long o. The "o-a," "o-w," "o-e," "o consonant e" and "o" spellings stand for the /ō/ sound. What sound does the "o-a" spelling make in the word "boat?" <pause> /ō/. Listen as your teacher continues with more long o spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for Long o>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ō/ sound each time you write the spelling.
Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the long o sound, let’s blend some words using this sound and other sounds we have learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.

/koooot/, cot. /kōōōt/, coat. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether’. Say the word nice and loud.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about crows. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. crow <pause>, beak <pause>, nut <pause>, branch. Look at the crow in the picture. What is the crow holding?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about crows. The word is rambunctious. Someone who is rambunctious is playful and full of energy.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, rambunctious>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words notorious>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “The Lowdown on Crows”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words rambunctious and notorious>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about crows? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 4 Student Book. The title of this story is "The Kind Crows.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: The Kind Crows. The picture shows crows, which are a type of bird.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: generous. To be generous means to be willing to share. She is generous with her money and gives it away to charities. How can you assist a friend? How can you be generous with a friend?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, generous>

audio.transcription: Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the word that names what the shiny yellow bead was made of.
What does Kenzo do that shows he is generous? Find sentences that answer the question.
Could this story happen in real life? Why or why not?
How have you been generous with someone who needed help? What did you do?
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write about the lesson you learned from this story and how you could use the lesson in your own life. <pause> Share your ideas with a partner before you write. Look back at the story for ideas.
Total Slides

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Oral Blending and Segmenting Words with Final Blends

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 4, Lesson 2. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 4.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 4 Student Book. Whisper read the story “The Kind Crows.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Oral Blending and Segmenting Words with Final Blends

audio.transcription: Listen as I say the following sounds: /p/ /a/ /s/ /t/.
Repeat the sounds and blend them to make a word. /paaassst/, past.
Now listen as your teacher says the following sounds. Blend them together to make a word.
Now let's segment a word into sounds. Listen as I say a word: past
Repeat the word and tap each sound as you say it. /p/ /a/ /s/ /t/
Now listen as your teacher says the following words. Say each word. Then say each word again as you tap each sound as you say it.

This is the sound-spelling card for long o. The "o-a," "o-w," "o-e," "o consonant e" and "o" spellings stand for the /ō/ sound. What sound does the "o-a" spelling make in the word "boat?" <pause> /ō/. Listen as your teacher continues with more long o spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling (boat) card for Long o>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ō/ sound each time you write the spelling.
Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the long o sound, let’s blend some words using this sound and other sounds we have learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.

/koooot/, cot. /kōōōt/, coat. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether’. Say the word nice and loud.
Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: said, here, look, me, play>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word said. Say the word with me. Said. Which sounds do you hear in said? /s/ /e/ /d/. Blend the sounds together.
Spell the word with me: s-a-i-d. The word "said" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: here, look, me, play.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about how goats can be lawnmowers. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. water <pause>, goat herd <pause>, grass <pause>, grazing. Look at the goats in the picture. What are the goats doing?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about how goats can be lawnmowers. The word is delicate. Something that is delicate can be easily damaged.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, delicate>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words alternative>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Living Lawnmowers”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words delicate and alternative>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about how goats can be lawnmowers? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 2 in your Unit 4 Student Book. The title of this text is "Mountain Goats.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Mountain Goats. Mountain goat is a special kind of goat that lives high up in the mountains where few other animals can live.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: adapt. To adapt means to change or adjust to what is around you. A duck has webbed feet that help it adapt to living by the water. How do you think a bear might adapt to cold weather?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, adapt>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the word that describes the weather in the mountains.
What body parts have helped the mountain goat adapt to living in the mountains? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Why are the mountains a good home for the mountain goat?
What is one thing you think is most interesting about the mountain goat? Why do you think so?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: List three to five facts that you learned about mountain goats. <pause> Draw a picture to accompany your list.

toc.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
toc.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 4, Lesson 3. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 4.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 4 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Mountain Goats” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.

This is the sound-spelling card for long o. The "o-a," "o-w," "o-e," "o consonant e" and "o" spellings stand for the /ō/ sound. What sound does the "o-a" spelling make in the word "boat?" <pause> /ō/. Listen as your teacher continues with more long o spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for Long o>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ō/ sound each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the long o sound, let’s blend some words using this sound and other sounds we have learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's find and circle all the words with "o-a".
Now, let's put a box around all the words with "o-w."

slides.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
slides.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word cot. <pause> Add the letter a after o to make the long o spelling. What word did you make? coat.
Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Make the word cot <pause>. Now change cot to coat. Which sound is different? Which letter will be different?

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Think about each sound in the word you are making. Use letter cards to spell the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the letter cards to build the words>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 4 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. These sentences contain words with long o and other phonics skills we have learned. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
Circle all the words with long o. <pause> Turn to a partner and read the words. Your teacher will listen in.
Write a sentence using the word raincoat. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word raincoat>

audio.transcription: Write a sentence using each of these word pairs: grow/road, most/joke.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word pairs grow/road, most/joke>

toc.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 4, Lesson 4. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 4.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 4 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences.
Listen as I read the following words: "row" <pause> "boat."
audio.notes: <visual: show the words row and boat>

audio.transcription: Now combine the words to make a new word. What new word did you form?
rowboat. <pause> "Rowboat" is a compound word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words row and boat and the word rowboat underneath them>

audio.transcription: A compound word is a word that is made up of two smaller words. "Rowboat" is made up of the words: "row" and "boat."
Looking for smaller words in a compound word can help you pronounce it and sometimes figure out its meaning.
Practice finding the smaller words and meanings of these compound words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words railroad, rainbow, windblown>

audio.transcription: This is the sound-spelling card for long o. The "o-a," "o-w," "o-e," "o consonant e" and "o" spellings stand for the /ō/ sound. What sound does the "o-a" spelling make in the word "boat?" <pause> /ō/. Listen as your teacher continues with more long o spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for Long o>

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Then, read each word as your teacher taps on it.
Select two words from the list. Write a sentence for each word.
Introduce High-Frequency Words. Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: see, she, try, about, because>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word see. Say the word with me. See. The word "see" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Spell the word with me: s-e-e. The letters "ee" maks the /ē/ sound in the word "see."
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: she, try, about, because

slides.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
Let's start with the word soap. Write the word soap.
Now write the word hold.
Spelling Booster: Let's write some more words. Listen to each word I say. Break apart the word sound by sound, then write the letter or spelling for each sound.
no
nose
low
slow
load
upload

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 4 Student Book. The title of this text is "Who Knows?" Point to each word as you read the title with me: Who Knows? These are riddles. A riddle is a tricky word puzzle that you use clues to solve. Read the riddles. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Find all the words in the riddles with long o spellings and circle them. <pause> Chorally read the circled words.
Write the sentence I say. Listen carefully and focus on one word at a time.

The first sentence is: Dad will load the stones on the truck. Say the sentence with me: Dad will load the stones on the truck. Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you segment, or break apart, each word and write a letter for each sound.
The second sentence is: Which box will hold the most? Say the sentence with me: Which box will hold the most? Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you if you need it.
Let's read each sentence out loud. Check your work. Your teacher will write each sentence. Correct your spellings if necessary.
Total Slides
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 4, Lesson 5. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 4.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 4 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Who Knows?” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
Let's review compound words. A compound word is a word that is made up of two smaller words, like the word "raincoat."
The word "raincoat" is made up of the words "rain" and "coat." Looking for smaller words in larger words can help you pronounce the larger words and sometimes figure out their meanings.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "raincoat" and the words "rain" and "coat" underneath it>

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "snowman." What smaller words do you see within the word "snowman"?
The words "snow" and "man" make up the word "snowman." A snowman is a man that is made of snow.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "snowman" and the words "snow" and "man" underneath it>

audio.transcription: Practice finding the smaller words in the following compound words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words: flagpole, bathrobe, sailboat, goldfish>

audio.transcription: Look at these words. Let's read the words together: oat, coal, coast, approach, mow, know, grow, shown. Now look at these two categories. This is the word oat. Read the word with me. <pause> Which category should I put oat under? <pause> Yes, oat goes in the oa- category because the word oat begins with oa-. With your partner, continue to sort the rest of the words.
audio.notes: <visual: show words oat, coal, coast, approach, mow, know, grow, shown> <visual: show word oat> <visual: show the sorting cards oa and ow pocket chart>

audio.transcription: What did you notice about the words in each group?
You may notice the oa- and ow- spelling in many words. As we read, let's look for words with oa- and ow-.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about mountain goats. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. mountain <pause>, mountain goat <pause>, horns <pause>, hoof <pause>, rocks. Look at the mountain goat in the picture. Where is the animal?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about mountain goats. The word is reside. The place where you reside is the place where you live.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, reside>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the steep>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Mountain Climbers on the Move”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words reside and steep>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about mountain goats? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 4 Student Book. The title of this text is "Where Are These Goats?” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Where Are These Goats? You will read about goats found in unusual places.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: unusual. Unusual means strange or different. A tree is an unusual place for a rabbit to live. What are some unusual things you have seen? Why were they unusual?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, unusual>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the word that names a machine that cuts grass.
What are some unusual, or strange, places where goats can be found? Find sentences that answer this question.
How are the goats in the city and those in trees alike?
Do you think goats would be happy living by your home? Why or why not?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Draw four boxes on a sheet of paper. <pause> Write an important fact about goats in each box. <pause> Use these facts to write a twelve sentence summary of the text. Share your ideas with a partner before you write.
Total Slides

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Delete Final Sound in a Blend

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 4, Lesson 6. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 4.

Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 4 Student Book. Whisper read the text “Where Are These Goats?” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Delete Final Sound in a Blend

audio.transcription: Listen as I say the following word: blow
Say the word blow without /l/. What's the new word? <pause> bow
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's delete the ending sound of a word. Listen as I say the following word: past
Say the word past without /t/. What's the new word? <pause> pass
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.

This is the sound-spelling card for long o. The "o-a," "o-w," "o-e," "o consonant e" and "o" spellings stand for the /ō/ sound. What sound does the "o-a" spelling make in the word "boat?" <pause> /ō/. Listen as your teacher continues with more long o spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for Long o>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ō/ sound each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Say the sound for each letter or spelling as your teacher points to it. Blend the sounds to read the word. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's review some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: here, look, me, play, said, see, she, try, about, because.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word here. Say the word with me: "here"
Spell the word with me: h-e-r-e. The word "here" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Then, use the word in a sentence.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: look, me, play, said, see, she, try, about, because.

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Use letter cards to spell the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the letter cards to build the words>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 4 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. These sentences contain words with long o and other phonics skills we have learned. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
Circle all the words with long o. <pause> Turn to a partner and read the words. Your teacher will listen in.
Write a sentence using the word open. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word open>

audio.transcription: Write a sentence using each of these word pairs: go/home, know/boat.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word pairs go/home, know/boat>

audio.transcription: Total Slides
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 4, Lesson 7. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 4.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 4 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Finally, find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.

This is the sound-spelling card for long o. The "o-a," "o-w," "o-e," "o consonant e" and "o" spellings stand for the /ō/ sound. What sound does the "o-a" spelling make in the word "boat?" <pause> /ō/. Listen as your teacher continues with more long o spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for Long o>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ō/ sound each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's review some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: look, here, me, play, said, see, she, try, about, because.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word look. Say the word with me: "look"
Spell the word with me: l-o-o-k. The word "look" is pronounced /l/ /o͝o/ /k/. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Then, use the word in a sentence.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: here, me, play, said, see, she, try, about, because.

Let's do some more work with this unit's high-frequency words. Read: Look at the high-frequency words. Read each word along with me. here, <pause> look, <pause> me, <pause> play, <pause> said, <pause> see, <pause> she, <pause> try, <pause> about, <pause> because.
audio.notes: <visual: show "here, look, me, play, said, see, she, try, about, because" as cards in pocket-chart pockets, add one blank pocket-row, show tray with only letters for the first word.> [intended for teacher to model the first word]

audio.transcription: Build: Now let's build a word together. Watch as your teacher spells the word.
Now use your letter cards to build all the words.
Write: Write each word. Then write a sentence using each word. For example, you can start a sentence with "I want ______ because ______." Read your sentences to a partner when you are done.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence frame "I want [blank] because [blank]." Then show "here, look, me, play, said, see, she, try, about, because" as cards in pocket-chart pockets underneath sentence frame>

audio.transcription: Now your teacher is going to make a word with letter cards. <pause> What is the word? <pause> Spell it together. <pause> Watch as your teacher scrambles the letters. Fix the spelling.
audio.notes: <visual: empty pocket rows with tray with letter cards for word, look>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 4 Student Book. The title of this text is "A Goat’s Hoof." Point to the word as you read the title with me: A Goat’s Hoof. This text tells about different parts of a goat’s hoof and how the hooves help the goat climb. It includes two diagrams and call‑outs. Diagrams help readers understand the parts of something that are important to remember.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: What do you notice or wonder about when viewing these diagrams?
Create a diagram with call-outs that show either your own hand or foot, or the paw of an animal that you know well.
Total Slides

toc.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
toc.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 4, Lesson 8. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 4.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 4 Student Book. Whisper read the text “A Goat’s Hoof.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Let's review compound words. Listen as I read the following words: "rain" <pause> "bow."
audio.notes: <visual: show the words rain and bow>

audio.transcription: Now combine the words to make a new word. What new word did you form?
rainbow. <pause> "Rainbow" is a compound word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words rain and bow and the word rainbow underneath them>

audio.transcription: Knowing the words that make up a compound word can help us figure out its meaning.
A rainbow is a “bow in the sky made by rain.”
Practice finding the smaller words and meanings of these compound words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words truckload, steamboat, bedpost>

audio.transcription: This is the sound-spelling card for long o. The "o-a," "o-w," "o-e," "o consonant e" and "o" spellings stand for the /ō/ sound. What sound does the "o-a" spelling make in the word "boat?" <pause> /ō/. Listen as your teacher continues with more long o spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for Long o>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ō/ sound each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's find and circle all the words with ow.
Now, let's put a box around all the words with -ing, -ful,or -less.

slides.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
slides.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word rob. <pause> Add the letter e after b to make the long o spelling. What word did you make? robe
audio.notes: <Show e-pocket chart here so the teacher can model this>

audio.transcription: Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Make the word rob <pause>. Now change rob to robe. Which sound is different? Which letter is different?

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about flamingos. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. flamingo <pause>, colony <pause>, beak <pause>, lagoon <pause>, chick. Look at the flamingos in the picture. What features do these animals have?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about flamingos. The word is hues. Hues are “shades of a color.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, hues>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, majestic>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Fabulous Flamingos.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words hues and majestic>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about flamingos? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 4 Student Book. The title of this story is "Lion and Mouse.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Lion and Mouse. This is a story about how a lion learns a lesson.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: powerful. Powerful means strong or mighty. Elephants are powerful animals. What do you picture when you hear the word powerful?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, powerful>

audio.transcription: Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the words that tell what Mouse did that made Lion angry?
Do you have to be big to be powerful? Why or why not? Use sentences from the story to answer the question.
The moral of the story is that everyone has value. What does that mean?
What are some ways a person might be powerful?
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Draw a picture to remember the important details in the text. Write captions that include words such as opened, woke, toe, swallow, go, groan, and ropes. <pause> Use your drawing to retell the story to a partner. Then, write your retelling.
Total Slides

toc.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 4, Lesson 9. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 4.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 4 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Lion and Mouse.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.

This is the sound-spelling card for long o. The "o-a," "o-w," "o-e," "o consonant e" and "o" spellings stand for the /ō/ sound. What sound does the "o-a" spelling make in the word "boat?" <pause> /ō/. Listen as your teacher continues with more long o spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for Long o>

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Let's blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Say the word nice and loud.
Select two words from the list. Write a sentence for each word.

slides.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
Let's start with these two words. Write the word stole.
Now write the word sold.
Finally, write this sentence: We drove on a toll road.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about gold. First, look at these four pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. bars <pause>, coin <pause>, bracelet <pause>, ring <pause>, artifact. Look at the coin in the picture. What color is the coin?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about gold. The word is precious. Something that is precious has great value.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, precious>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, glimpse>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “What’s So Great About Gold?”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words, precious and glimpse>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about gold? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 4 Student Book. The title of this story is "King Midas.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: King Midas. This is an old story about a king who loved gold.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: selfish. To be selfish means to only care about oneself, and to not share. The selfish boy took all the treats for himself. What are some ways a person could be selfish?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, selfish>

audio.transcription: Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
What did King Midas love more than anything else? Find the word that answers the question.
What did King Midas wish for? Find the sentence that answers the question.
What lesson does King Midas learn about being greedy and selfish?
How could you use the lesson from this story in your own life? Give some examples.
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write a story about what King Midas does the day after this story takes place. <pause> Share your ideas with a partner before you write.
Total Slides

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Blend and Segment Multisyllabic Words by Syllable

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 4, Lesson 10. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 4.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 4 Student Book. Whisper read the story “King Midas.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Blend and Segment Multisyllabic Words by Syllable

audio.transcription: Listen as I say the following syllables: pan-cake
Repeat the syllables and blend them to make a word. pan-cake, pancake.
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following syllables. Blend the syllables to make a word.
Now we will segment words into syllables. Listen as I say the following word: snowman
Repeat the word and segment it into the syllables you hear. Snowman, snow-man.
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words. Segment each word into the syllables you hear.
Let's review compound words. A compound word is a word that is made up of two smaller words, like the word "oatmeal." What smaller words do you see within the word "oatmeal?"
The words "oat" and "meal" make up the word "oatmeal." Oatmeal is a meal that is made of oats.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "oatmeal" and the words "oat" and "meal" underneath it>

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "tiptoe." What words do you see within the word "tiptoe"?
The words "tip" and "toe" make up the word "tiptoe." To "tiptoe" means to walk using the tips of your toes.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "tiptoe" and the words "tip" and "tiptoe" underneath it>

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "notepad." What words do you see within the word "notepad"?
The words "note" and "pad" make up the word "notepad." A notepad is a pad where you write notes.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "note" and the words "pad" and "notepad" underneath it>

audio.transcription: Practice adding smaller words to the following words to see how many new words you can make.
Let's make a word ladder. I will give you a clue for each word to write on the word ladder.
This is something cars drive on.
Change the last sound in road to name a kind of insect.
Change the last sound in roach to name a way to cook things.
Change the beginning letter in roast to name bread that has been browned.
Change the ending blend in toast to name a kind of animal.
Change one letter in toad to make a word that is the past form of tell.
Let's do some more work with this unit's high-frequency words. Look at the high-frequency words.
audio.notes: <visual: here, look, me, play, said, see, she, try, about, because>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher reads a high-frequency word from the list. Point to the word. Read the word. Spell the the word aloud.

Now build each high-frequency word using letter cards. Then work with a partner. Take turns scrambling the letters in the words. Rebuild each word. Watch as your teacher models scrambling and rebuilding the word "here."
audio.notes: <visual: pocket chart with 1st word letter cards: here>

audio.transcription: Now your teacher will ask you to read and write some words to check on your progress. Congratulations on all your hard work in Unit 4!
Total Slides
